text: hi everyone uh let's go ahead and get started um i want to thank everyone for for joining today uh
my name is arun sundaram i'm a product manager with aws storage services
and i'm excited today to talk about a service we launched back in january of this year
called the aws storage gateway so i'll start today a little bit high
level i'll talk through some of the key use cases for the gateway and then i'll jump into a little bit of
the architecture and some some tips on on configuration
so where i'd where i'd like to start is uh this chart from idc
uh that gives you a sense of storage growth since 2006.
uh now the chart shows the data in exabytes which probably isn't too applicable to to folks in this room but
i think what is applicable is the the shape of that graph right where you know a lot of you
probably were used to dealing with gigabytes of data and you're probably now dealing with terabytes or you're dealing with terabytes of data
and you're now having to deal with uh petabytes of data and in in talking to customers what we
found is uh you know this you know in spite of this this data growth that you're seeing
in your organization you're being forced to do more with a limited set of resources
and we're also hearing that the traditional technologies uh and processes that you have
in place on premise just aren't scaling to meet the demands of your organization
so whether this is you know unstructured file storage like departmental file shares home directories or
you know backup infrastructure infrastructure for disaster recovery or
archival what you're having to do is you know place bets on the amount of storage that you need to procure
and you know if you're if you're if you procure too too much storage you're left with underutilized capacity
uh idle idle storage high capital costs and if you purchase too little well then
you're faced with having to do frequent hardware refreshes which can be time consuming
expensive and potentially risky so then what happens is you know usually
the the backlash is you know restrictive user quotas to say hey i know you're looking for 10 terabytes of storage but
right now we can give you five terabytes and so what we're hearing from customers both you know small businesses and large
multinational enterprises is not only is this a this data growth a
cost issue but it's also impacting agility right it's it's impacting your ability to move
forward quickly as a business and this is where uh the amazon simple
storage service can help right i know we're we're going to be talking more about amazon s3
tomorrow in detail but i'll cover it quickly at a high level
so amazon's simple storage service uh it's storage for the internet uh
provides a a bucket where you can you can put objects into that bucket there's no limit to the number of objects you
can put you can scale up and down on demand and you only pay for the stores that you use
so the key benefit there is that capacity problem is removed right
because you no longer have to pay have to deal with underutilized capacity with s3 you're able to scale you only pay
again for what you use you don't have to worry about you know dealing with provisioning storage for
for your users uh you also don't want you no longer have to deal with the maintenance of that storage
whether it's backup storage whether it's primary storage you know reliability power cooling of
that storage s3 handles all that for you transparently
you also don't have to deal with the hardware refresh cycle that i talked about right every every you know three
or so years when your support contract ends or your hardware reaches end of life and you need to move that to new
hardware s3 handles all that transparently for you while providing a highly secure solution
that's comparable to you know what enterprises are running in in their own data centers i'll drill into
a couple of these aspects in a little more detail so the first is you know i talked about how s3 provides a high
level of reliability so we look at that in in two ways the first is around availability so s3
is designed for four nines of availability and when we think about availability we really mean
up time of the service so if you're doing a put of an object into s3 or a get or you're listing the
objects in s3 the ability to ensure that when you perform
those request calls that the service will respond the other way we look at reliability is
from a durability perspective and when i say durability i mean ensuring that your data is protected from from loss
right so that when you need to access your data it's recoverable and with that s3 is designed for 11 9's
of durability so how does s3 achieve this high level of durability
when when you when you store data with s3 the the service redundantly stores
your objects across multiple devices across multiple facilities
within an aws region so when you actually put an object into s3
s3 redundantly stores that data across multiple facilities before returning success
so you know that when you receive a success on your on your put request you know that your data has been
redundantly stored across multiple regions sorry multiple facilities
s3 is also designed to deliver a high level of security and and we look at security from
a networking perspective from a from a software perspective and from a infrastructure perspective
so we have a number of certifications in place like sock one type two iso 27001
we have strict procedures in place to control who has access to the infrastructure in our data center
s3 also has features around encryption enabling you to store your data in s3
with aes 256 encryption using what we call the server side encryption
capability and when you use sse server side encryption
s3 encrypts your data with an encryption key and then encrypts that encryption key
with it with a separate key and those those keys are stored uh in separate locations
but you know s3 is designed for you know storage for the internet right
it's designed for access over http and it's designed for
it provides a rest interface and what we've heard from customers is that for for new workloads for new
applications s3 makes you know total sense it's a no-brainer right you just write your
application to work with s3's rest interface but what we've also heard is you know
when it comes to that data growth i was talking about you know backup storage file share storage
we've we've you know a lot a lot of the a lot of the storage comes from existing legacy workloads legacy applications
that customers are running on premise and for those applications
you know the value of s3 is still there right you still want to be able to store your data in s3 but you know we've heard requests for
the ability to use those existing applications to store data in s3
and so that brings me to the aws storage gateway so the aws storage gateway service
its primary motivation is to enable you to bridge your existing on-premise
applications with aws cloud storage
and we do this by providing a virtual appliance that you download from our website
and you then install on a host running in your data center
now you know when we initially initially launched the service back in january
there was a you know a number of customers that that thought that you know when we said virtual appliance that
you know they might actually get up be getting a box from amazon.com in the mail right with an actual physical
appliance in it and and i want to highlight that that is not the case right so it's a
virtual appliance so it's software that you would download from our our management console
so when we think about the the storage gateway service one one of the key tenets that we had
was to ensure compatibility right because we're talking about existing applications
working with amazon s3 and so we think about compatibility
from from three perspectives so the first is around the deployment of
the gateway itself and so the we've made the storage gateway deployable as a standard vmware image
uh again you can download from our website and you can deploy it on a host in your data center running vmware
hypervisor and you can use uh you can use a paid version or the free version of
vmware's hypervisor the the second way we looked at compatibility was from the protocol
itself and so with the storage gateway you can create iscsi storage volumes
that are backed by amazon s3 that you can then mount to your
your uh on-premise application servers so for example if you're if you're running a windows application server you
can mount an iscsi storage gateway volume and it'll show up as for example a d drive
which essentially allows you to mount amazon s3 as a d drive to your on-premise application server
and the third thing we looked at was was performance right because when we're dealing with this this data growth
your end user shouldn't have to worry about whether the data is being stored locally or in s3 right all they care about is
that the data is being stored durably it's being stored securely and that they're continuing to
uh have the same experience in accessing that storage so so to provide that seamless
compatible experience you know part of it is the protocol iscsi but then part of it is performance and
so the way we've achieved that is by storing the data up in s3 but keeping
recently accessed frequently accessed really your active data set locally as well
for low latency access we've also designed the storage gateway
to be flexible so we had a number of customers that came to us and said
you know we want to be able to continue to store our primary data locally you know all of our primary data locally for
low latency access but then we'd like to be able to take you know point in time snapshots of that
data and store those as backups in amazon s3 for off-site
durable backups and so for for that for that um request we we
delivered gateway stored volumes so gateway stored volumes are iscsi storage volumes that are stored locally
on hardware in your data center and what the storage gateway then does is
it takes that data and uploads it transparently in the background to amazon s3
for for backups but we also had a number of customers that said look we want even more cost
savings than that we want to be able to actually store our primary storage uh up in s3
but we want to keep our our frequently accessed data locally right and so you know whether it was
backup applications being able to store those backups in s3 or or file shares
being able to store your file share storage in s3 for for that use case we we delivered
gateway cache volumes and so gateway cache points again are iscsi storage volumes but in this case
the the storage volume data is stored up in s3 not locally and then we're just keeping a cache of of that data on
premise in either the gateway stored cached volume offering or the gateway cached
volume offering we provide the ability to take point in time snapshots of that data for backups and those snapshots are
stored in s3 so you so you may ask hey if i'm using gateway cache volumes and my volume data
is already up in s3 and it's being stored with 11 lines of durability then why do i need to take snapshots
so the reasoning there is for versioning purposes right if you want to preserve prior versions of your data so for
example if there's an unintended user action on premise and your user accidentally deletes a bunch of data and
you need to recover to a prior version of your volume you can create a new volume from a
snapshot that you've taken we've also added the ability to to support bandwidth throttling so we had
customers that said hey you know i want to be able to store my data up in s3 but you know i may need to throttle
that down during the daytime and and increase the the bandwidth that's available to the gateway in the evening
and so you can you can configure that through both our management console uh as well as through
um our api and then and then finally we we supported uh
both both linux and uh windows iscsi initiators
right so that allows you then to mount your storage gateway volume to both
a linux on premise application server and a windows on premise application server
so i'll now take you through uh three of the use cases that we targeted with the storage gateway and i'll talk through a
little bit about you know how what what the architecture would look like
the so the first is you know as i mentioned already corporate file sharing right so you know home directories
departmental file shares um and so and so with with with file shares
with the storage gateway you can now store using gateway cache volumes your store your file share storage up in s3
and just keep your recently accessed files uh on premise
and so if we look at how how you know what the architecture would look like in that model
so on the left-hand side you see your data center a host running the
vmware hypervisor and the storage gateway virtual machine and on the front end the the storage
gateway would would expose an iscsi interface uh that you would then mount to your uh on premise you know either
windows or or linux file server and then your users would then connect to that file server over
sifs or nfs right so to them it would appear as just another network share
when your user writes a file to the to the file server it's then sent over iscsi to the storage gateway volume
we store that file locally on either direct attached san or nas storage in
your data center and then we asynchronously upload that file that piece of data up to amazon s3
so the reason we're storing it locally is because again we're keeping recently written recently red data on premise for
low latency access right and then we're uploading it to s3 over an encrypted ssl connection
and we're storing it encrypted in s3 using s3's server side encryption capability
if your user then does a read of a file so if they go to the file share and they double click a file to open it
the storage gateway will check the local cache for that file if it's there they'll deliver it over
iscsi to the file server if the file isn't there then the storage gateway will grab that file from s3
download it and present it to your user so for files that are again you know
most files that are are recently read are the files that were recently written and so for those files your users will
continue to get local performance if your user tries to access a file that's stored up in s3 you know they may
see it you know a couple second delayed depending on where your location is compared to the uh
amazon s3 region that you're storing data in but with the with the file share model what this allows you to do then is to
you know for example let's say you're storing 10 terabytes of file share data locally today you can move that that 10 terabytes of
data over to a gateway cache volume up in amazon s3 and your users can then start accessing
that volume over over their file share if you then need to add more storage
you can simply increase your usage of your volume in s3 and you don't you no longer have to scale on premise you no
longer have to add any more storage locally and because you're only paying for what you use in s3
you know as as you as you increase your usage in s3 you know that's what you're going to be paying for so you can you can provision up to a 32 terabyte volume
up in s3 but you won't be paying for any of that s3 storage until you actually start storing data
the next use case is around backups so uh you know whether it's
something like tsm or an application like backup exec or veeam you know these applications are able to write over an
iscsi interface to disk so for example we have you know a large university using the storage gateway
today where you know previously they were backing up their data uh
to a to a secondary data center that was pretty close to their primary data center and they were running into two issues so one was in their secondary
data center they were running out of out of storage and the second issue was
they felt that their secondary data center was too close to their primary from a disaster recovery perspective
so now what they've done is they've taken their existing backup application and they've simply pointed it at a
storage gateway volume and they're now storing their backups in s3 they no longer have to worry about you
know scaling that on-premise uh storage and so in that in that model again the
the backup application server would connect to the to the gateway over to the gateway volume over iscsi
and then as the backups are written to the to the gateway we store the back the the backups
locally and then we also upload it to s3 and then when the from the backup
applications perspective it doesn't know whether the data is being stored in locally or it's being stored in s3 right all it sees is the
iscsi interface and we're transparently in the background handling you know where the retrieval of that data
should come from the the last use case i want to touch on
is disaster recovery so i mentioned that the
storage gateway enables you to take snapshots of your volumes and store those snapshots in amazon s3
sorry well we've added the uh ability to
access those snapshots from amazon ec2 and so this allows you in the event that
your on-premise infrastructure is no longer available you can reconstitute operations
in amazon ec2 and so the snapshots that you store through your on-premise gateway
you can then access from ec2 when you need to to recover
so the value here is you know if you think about a traditional dr uh setup you probably have you know
your primary data center and your secondary data center and you're having to pay for all that compute
infrastructure in your secondary data center even though you know you only need access to it either when you have a
test or in the rare event and hopefully this never happens that you actually have a dr event
but with using ec2 ec2 enables you to only pay for the compute instances when you actually have
to use them so if you're using aws and ec2 for disaster recovery
you only have to spin up and use those ec2 instances either when you want to test your dr workflow
or when you actually have a dr event if we drill in a little bit deeper into
how you access the data from ec2 so we uh there's a service called amazon
ebs elastic block store um it essentially provides block storage volumes for
your ec2 instances running in the cloud enables your applications running in ec2
to have low inc access to their data so ebs allows you to take snapshots of
your of your cloud-based eps volumes and store those snapshots in s3 as ebs
snapshots well the the snapshots that you take from your storage gateway volumes
are also stored in s3 as ebs snapshots so what that means then is
you can create an ebs volume from that snapshot attach it to an ec2 instance and then
you now have access to the data that you wrote from your on-premise application
you would need to pre-bundle your instance with what we call an amazon machine image
with your operating system and with the application that that you're running on premise to be able to access that data
so we've uh we've been getting started with the with the storage gateway a pretty a pretty straightforward process
you'd need to first provision a host on premise
running like i said vmware hypervisor and then you would download
our software from from our management console deploy it on your host
and then you would allocate on-premise storage to that uh virtual machine and again that can be from
either direct attached storage nas storage or sand storage so if you're if you're already using a san on premise
and you want to continue to use that investment you've already made you can utilize the san for your cash
and then once you've done that you would go to our management console or use our api and type in the ip address of your
gateway vm and what that allows us to do is to then tie your aws account to to the gateway
that you've deployed and then finally you would select the uh in terms of activation you would select
the aws region so which amazon s3 region do you want to store your data in
and once you've done that you can then start creating and mounting iscsi storage volumes
to your on-premise application servers and start storing data
so if we look at the architecture what i'm highlighting here is the architecture of
a gateway cached volume setup so if we drill into that a little bit more as i mentioned your volume storage
is stored up in amazon s3 and you can then take snapshots of that
and store them in s3 now now snapshots are differentials right so so the first snapshot you take
is a complete copy of your volume but if you then write you know a couple of additional blocks to your volume and
you take a snapshot the second snapshot is only going to store those incremental two blocks of
data we're also compressing all the data both on upload and download and we're
compressing both the volume storage and the snapshot storage in amazon s3
if we look at the gateway virtual machine and the storage that you allocate for it
there's two types of storage that you would need to allocate to your gateway so the first is the cash storage right
and so the cash storage is you know your your local cash for cashing your
frequently access data right your reads and your and your rights and then we ask you to allocate what we
call upload buffer the upload buffer is essentially the cue
to get data up to amazon s3 so when a write happens over the iscsi
connection we store that data both in your cache storage because it's a recently written piece of data and we also store it in
your upload buffer to queue it up for upload to s3 we're constantly uploading that data to
uh s3 right so there's not a there's not sort of a step that you would need to take to say okay upload this to s3 as soon as the
data hits the upload buffer it immediately enters the queue for upload to
amazon s3 and so you can imagine during the course of the day your upload buffer will be
filling up and and the usage in it will be filling up and contracting you know depending upon your network connection
depending upon how much data is is flowing in so i want to show uh

so if we look at um you know how to actually size your
your uh upload buffer so when you think about sizing the
upload buffer again it's about queuing the data before it gets up to s3 you want to think about the approximate
amount of data that you're going to be writing on a daily basis so if your backup application is you know writing
you know a terabyte a day then you would want your upload buffer to be about a terabyte in size
um but it's it is recommended that your upload buffer is at least 150 gigabytes
in size the sizing of your cache storage depends
on the use case so if you're looking at the storage gateway for a backup type use case
then you'd want your cash storage to be at least the size of your upload buffer
i'll get into why in in just a little bit if you're looking at it for for example
a file share use case where you know you want your cache to be larger to store data for quick reads
then you know our recommendation is to look at the amount of storage you have today in that file share and allocate about 20
of it so what we've seen is this this will vary but what we've seen is typically about 20
of the the file share will be actively accessed um so if you have 10 terabytes of file
share storage you can create a you know 32 terabyte volume up in s3 to store that data but you'd want to add about
two terabytes of cash storage locally you can always add more cash storage
you can't remove cash storage and the reason is is because your cash storage is
your durable store of data so if we look at the path that data takes
when it hits the gateway we store it uh on your cash storage dis
right and then we acknowledge the write back to your application right so it's not like we're
writing it to s3 and then acknowledging the right that happens transparently in the background
so when you think about the durability of the data you're writing to the gateway well so once it's sorted up in s3 you're
getting eleven nines of durability but until then the the durability that
you're getting is really dependent upon the durability of your cash storage
right so if you're running let's say raid 5 or raid 6 on premise today for your file share
storage you'd want your cash storage to also be backed by raid 5 or raid 6.
the data is also written to as i said it's written to the cash drawer and it's also written to the upload buffer
but for the upload buffer we're simply you know writing it to memory and then we're uploading it to s3 so your cache
storage is really the durable data store so what that means then is your cache
storage needs to be large enough to store your dirty rights and when i
say dirty rights i mean data that hasn't yet been uploaded to s3
and so that's why when you think about a backup use case right so for a backup use case you may say look i just want to
store all my backups in s3 i'm rarely ever going to access my backups when i do you know i'm okay with the the
backups not being locally so so why do i need any cash storage at all and that's because
your cash storage is that durable store so your upload buffer you know does need to be large enough to store uh the dirty
data but but so does your cash storage right so so what happens if you know either of
these fill up right what what happens in in in that event where what are the error error error cases
here so if your upload buffer fills up
then uh the cash storage you know will continue to be able to process reads and writes
from your application and we'll now start uploading data from your cache directly to s3
but you won't be able to take snapshots during that time period because the upload buffer also tracks
snapshots if your cash if your cash storage fills up well
i mean that's fine right i mean ideally your cash should always be full of data right if it's not full of data and you
do a read well we'll we'll we'll put that piece of data in your cache right but what you want to avoid is your cache
getting full of dirty data and so we have we have alarms in place so when you go through the process of
setting up a gateway we by default set up alarms such that you get notified in the event
uh that your upload buffer fills up you get notified in the event that your cache storage fills up with dirty data
because what happens when your cash storage fills up is now we have no no place to put that
dirty data right and so we have to we have to stop the rights over iscsi we have to block future rights from coming
in until we can upload that data to s3 so you want to avoid that condition and
that is why you can add more cache storage but you can't remove cache storage because the cache is storing
your dirty data so if you remove storage you're potentially removing data that hasn't yet been
durably uploaded to amazon s3
we also recommend that you allocate separate disks for your cache
and your upload buffer and so if i'll jump back to to the diagram to explain it so so the reason
is the the cache is about optimizing the performance over iscsi right it's handling the reads and
writes from your on-premise application and the upload buffer is about optimizing performance to s3 it's about
it's about pushing data as quickly as possible compressing that data and pushing it as quickly as possible to s3
so ideally you want to have two separate disks so you have two separate spindles one handling the i o from your
application one handling the i o uh to and from s3 and so if you're looking at
it from a vmware perspective that would be you know two separate data stores
now this now come back to the point i made earlier uh which is around quick format and full format right so
again you're paying for the volume usage that you store up in s3 so if you provision a 32 terabyte volume
you haven't stored any data yet you're not paying for any of that that volume usage right
if you then go to windows and you do a full format well windows is going to write you know even if it's zeros it's going to write chunks to the entire
volume and we're seeing that data over iscsi we're just going to upload those blocks
up to s3 now it's highly compressible but it's no longer you know zero gigabytes of storage
right so you want to be very careful when you're creating a new volume from scratch that you use the the quick format uh
option similarly um from a virus scanning perspective
right if if you're uh you want when you're when you're running virus scanning on the the volume
the the iscsi volume you want to use a virus scanning software that'll do the scanning on reads and on writes
you you ideally don't want to be running a virus scanning software that you know for example once a week goes through and
scans your uh entire volume right because you can imagine then that
your cash storage is about keeping your frequently accessed data so
in the event that your virus scan software then starts reading all the data it'll download all the data from amazon s3 to your
cache storage right and then that'll impact the performance your users are seeing
because their recently accessed files will now be essentially evicted uh from from from the local cache
so you wanna you wanna make sure that uh your virus scanning is run on uh just the reads and writes that are
happening to um ss3 so so with that um you know i hope i
